These numbers are a complete flip from where New Yorkers stood on the issue just six years ago. New York State voter attitudes about gay marriage have shifted dramatically since April 15, 2004, when Quinnipiac University first asked about gay marriage and found voters opposed the measure 55-37 percent, said Maurice Carroll, director of the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute.
